Award.AwardTitle: CNH: The Dynamics of Multi-Scalar Adaptation in Megacities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Megacities (defined as cities with populations over 10 million) are highly vulnerable to environmental change but their size and complexity can make successful adaptation difficult. This interdisciplinary research project will study the challenge of reducing vulnerability to increased flooding, chronic water scarcity, and associated health problems in one of the world's largest metropolitan areas. Residents, businesses and public agencies in megacities respond to extremes in disparate and often uncoordinated ways, and these actions (such as changes in land use and infrastructure) may unintentionally create hazardous conditions in other parts of the city. The project will produce a dynamic systems model to explore how the individual responses of specific populations to different future scenarios of environmental change may affect one another and produce unintended consequences. As a decision-support tool, the model will enable decision-makers to test how altering risk-management priorities or adjusting the geographic focus of interventions aimed at dealing with changing climatic conditions could lead to improved overall results. The model will be developed for use in the study locale and would be readily adaptable for reducing risks from changing environmental conditions in complex urban environments across the globe.

The project will be implemented in close collaboration with the National Autonomous University of Mexico City and local stakeholders. Four case studies of vulnerable regions within Mexico City will be conducted to characterize the complexity of residents' experience of hazards and their response strategies. City-level analyses will capture the institutional context of decision -making and the mandates, intervention strategies, and priorities of city-level agencies and actors. A biophysical model will be developed to simulate the impact of land-use change and infrastructure modification on the city's hydro-climatic system. Agent-based modeling will be developed to simulate the responses of residents and city-level agencies to spatially differentiated hydro-climatic risk, with the outputs from this model linked to the hydro-climatic system. A geographic information system embedded in a multi-criteria decision-analysis framework will permit the exploration of different scenarios of hazard response in a spatially explicit manner, thereby facilitating decision making concerning adaptation to changing hydro-climatic conditions. The project will support the interdisciplinary and cross-cultural education and training of U.S. and Mexico.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The MEGADAPT (MEGAcity-ADAPTation) project conceptualized urban vulnerability as the product of social and political relations that materialize in decisions about the built environment, which in turn shape social exposure to environmental risk. The central product of the project is a dynamic system model, MEGADAPT, simulating the spatial and temporal patterns of flooding and water scarcity in Mexico City. The model integrates data on the mental models and decision criteria of water managers and vulnerable residents into a multi-agent model. This multi-agent model interacts dynamically with associated biophysical models to simulate flooding and water scarcity distribution in the mega-city under changing governance and climate change scenarios. The model thus serves as a decision-support tool for exploratory analysis of the drivers of urban vulnerability and potential opportunities for risk reduction.
Engaging with theory and concepts from decision making under deep uncertainty, social-ecological analysis, urban political-ecology and institutional analysis, MEGADAPT served as means of transdisciplinary research on the interaction of social, hydrological and infrastructural factors in creating and perpetuating urban vulnerability. This model represents a significant advance over many models used in urban decision support today by simulating social-ecological "double coupling": i.e., concurrent decision-making in response to risk exposure by households and city managers, the response of the biophysical environment to those decisions, and then, over time, the modification of the decision criteria of agents as they learn from the effects of their decisions on the urban landscape. The preferences, understanding and decision-criteria of diverse stakeholders were elicited in participatory workshops, interviews and focus groups and analyzed through a novel process and accompanying software for incorporation into MEGADAPT. Residents' expression of water-related grievances was determined to be a significant feedback, connecting residents' risk exposure and public sector action in vulnerability dynamics. Spatial patterns of both flooding/ponding and water scarcity were found to be statistically correlated with gastrointestinal disease in the city.
Model results, shared in multiple participatory workshops with stakeholders, revealed how decision preferences drive infrastructure investments in specific neighborhoods, reinforcing spatial and socio-economic inequities in water access and flood risk exposure over time. MEGADAPT scenarios of watershed urbanization and decentralized water supply under climate change and different degrees of budgetary constraint revealed heterogeneity landcover-runoff-flooding relationships across the city's watershed, as well as the potential for localized interventions in water supply to address inequities in vulnerability. The MEGADAPT model demonstrates the relevance of cognitive and socio-political drivers of vulnerability to flooding and scarcity, and the implications in uneven patterns of residents' exposure to risk. The model has been captured in computational infrastructureto facilitate its application in other megacity contexts, such that the methodology and procedure can be replicated.
The project provided new avenues of international institutional collaboration, strengthening ties between Arizona State University and the Laboratorio Nacional de Ciencias de Sostentabilidad of the Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico in Mexico City.  Graduate and undergraduate students in both universities were involved in collaborative efforts of data collection, analysis, research presentation and stakeholder engagement, resulting in three graduate theses and an undergraduate thesis, all completed by women pursuing careers in sustainability science. The project's approach and findings have been presented to Mexico City's Legislature, the Environment Ministry (SEDEMA), the Water Ministry (SACMEX) and the Mexico City's new Resilience Department of the Risk Management Ministry (SGIRPC), as well as disseminated through numerous international conferences with differing thematic emphases such as urban resilience, decision-making under uncertainty, multi-criteria decision analysis, climate change adaptation, and social transformation. The project has produced over 20 academic articles, maintains an active website and has continually engaged residents, policy makers, city managers and the wider academic community in participatory workshops, public presentations and ongoing collaborative endeavors.
